body.head: p 345 (28 October) ( Lord chamberlain's warrant book)

div.ab: Another warrant Another: ie, another warrantfor Iohn Rodes of ye fortune Playhouse vpon ye complaint of the blackfryers Company for selling their Playes. eodem eodem: ie, 28 October 1639 Ioseph Butler messenger.

head.title: Deposition of William Finch in Lisle v. Dulwich College

div.ab:
Ex parte Tobie Lisle vnius Defendentis ad sectam
Magistri guardianis et alium de Collegie God guift
in Dulwiche Comitatu Surreia querentium Testes examinati per Henricum Peyton Armigerum in Canccellaria Examinatorem
per Ordinem huius Curie generalis Datum 16to Novembris
1649/
William ffinche of the parishe of St Bennetes Paules wharfe London haberdasher aged 50 yeares or thereaboutes sworne &c/

That hee hath knowne Thomas Allen named for one of the plaintiffes in this suit these 14 yeares past or thereaboutes & Tobias Lisle named for one of the Defendantes heerein these 20 yearees past or thereaboutes/

That he did receave all the of Mr ffinney & Mr Smith in the article named all the profites that he this Deponent could get of them for five shares in the ffortune playhouse And this Deponent did ʌallwayes within two or three Dayes after this Deponent had receaved any money of the said parties pay vnto Robert Bankes or Arthur Minshaw in the article named for the proffitt of two shares & a halfe of the said playhouse & to one Mr ʌArthur Iohnston A souldier the proffit ʌof one share of the said house which was one Mr Barkers share & this Deponent did allso pay the proffites of halfe a share in the said house to mr Iames Earle & the proffites of one share thereof to one Robert Grymes for the share of
one Thomas Grymes
:letters lost along tear at crease; Interrogatory reads one Thomas Grymes
: 40mm of text lost due to tear at crease linehaue
: 45mm of text lost due to to tear at crease Grymes & this Deponent th oe the profit of five shares in the said house ever since the Defendant Tobias Lisle had any thinge to Doe ʌ the with said playhouse And saith that the two now produced acquittances the one of them bearing Date the 16 of Iuly 1648 for payment of 2 li.: 1 s. vnto the said Iames Earle & the other bearing date the 19 of Iune 1648 for payment of 4 li.: 3 s.: vnto the said Arthur Iohnston are the same acquittances which the said Iames Earle and Arthur Iohnston gave this Deponent vppon this Deponentes payment of moneys vnto them for the last proffites of the said share & halfe share of the said playhouse And this Deponent Doth in his conscience beleeve that the Defendant Lisle hath payed the summe of 100 li. more for the rent & repaire of the said playhouse then ever he the said Defendant Lisle receaved out of the profites thereof which is all he saith that he can materially depose to this Interrogatorie/

That he Did leave the Defendant Thomas ʌTobias Lisle complaine vnto the Complainant ʌ Thomas Allen as he came out of an alehouse which was then kept by one Pittes neer the ffortune in Golden lane that he the said Thomas Allen did mainteyne Mathew Smith in the article allso named to keepe possession of the said playhouse & that he the said Smith did lett the said house to players ffencers and
Dancers on the rope vntill it would bee pulled downe whereto (which was afterwardes done in parte) wherevnto the said plaintiff Thomas Allen replyed that the said Smith should be due soe ʌfor that he the said Allen did know a reason for the same which is all he saith that he can depose to this Interrogatory/

That he this Deponent & Thomas Hoare in the article named were present when Mathias Allen herein named who was late Master of Dulwiche Colledg & the now plaintiff who is at present Master thereof did agree with the Defendant Lisle that if he the said Defendant Lisle would take 2 Leases of 2 shares & a halfe share of the said playhouse in trust for Mary Minshaw & Suzan Cade in the article named on such condicions as they the said Mathias & Thomas Allen would put into the same & would pay soe much money as was then in arreare of rent that then the said Mathias & Thomas would if the Defendant Lisle desire it pay the said Defendant Lisle the ʌat the end of 4 yeares 74 li.: 1 s. 00. oblatus which the said Lisle paid for the same & Interest for it with all other charges & damages that the said Defendant should susteyne thereby And saith that he this Deponent & the said Thomas Hoare did subscrybe their names vnto the now produced Agreement conteyned in one sheet of paper beareinge Date the second day of Iuly Anno Domini 1639 & he doth acknowledge that the name of William ffinche soe subscrybed as a witnes to the said Agreement is of the proper handwritinge of this Deponent which is all hee saith that he can Depose to this Interrogatory/
To the rest &c/

In the meanetime let me tell ye a lamentable Tragedie, acted by the Prelacie, against the poore Players of the Fortune Play-house, which made them sing
Fortune my foe, why dost thou frown on me? &c.
or they having gotten a new old Play, called The Cardinalls conspirace, whom they brought upon the stage in as great state as they could, with Altars, Images, Crosses, Crucifixes, and the like
like, like: also written as a catchword at the foot of B2 to set forth his pomp and pride. But wofull was the sight to see how in the middest of all their mirth, the Pursevants came and seazed upon the poore Cardinall, and all his Consorts, and carryed them away. And when they were questioned for it, in the High Commission Court , they pleaded Ignorance, and told the Archbishop, that they tooke those examples of their Altars, Images, and the like, from Heathen Authors. This did somewhat asswage his anger, that they did not bring him on the Stage : But yet they were fined for it, and after a little imprisonment gat their liberty. And having nothing left them but a few old Swords and Bucklers, they fell to Act the Valiant Scot, which they Played five dayes with great applause, which vext the Bishops worse than the other, insomuch as they were forbidden Playing it any more, and some of them prohibited ever Playing againe.

Well (quoth Willie) let the Bishops be angry as they will, we have acted the Valiant Scot bravely at Berwicke: and if ever I live to come to London, Ile make one myselfe to make up the number, that it may be Acted thereto, and that with a new addition; for I can tell thee, here’s matter enough, and ye ken that I can Fence bravely and slish slash, with the best of them.

Vox Borealis was probably written by Richard Overton; however, the pamphlet claims to have been printed in 'the yeare coming on, 1641,' which may indicate its appearance during January–March 1640/1. This edition has an ink annotation, 'Novemb: 1640.' Archbishop Laud, a key figure in the pamphlet, had been imprisoned since 18 December 1640. Bentley suspected that the anecdote is a later telling of an earlier incident reported in May 1639, but it is possible, however, that the story is apocryphal. (See Dale B.J. Randall, Winter Fruit (Kentucky, 1995), 22–3, and Gerald Eades Bentley, The Jacobean and Caroline Stage (Oxford, 1966), vol 1, p 278, and vol 5, p 1235.)

body.head: p 112 (9 October) ( Manor court, freeholders' inquest: defaulters)

div.ab: At this Courte the wardens of Godsguifte Colledge are amerced in iiij d. per poll for not appeareinge at this Courte to doe their suite & service

body.head: p 101 (2 October) ( Manor court, freeholders' inquest)

div.ab: Item Thomas Allen gentleman did this Courte doe his fealtie for the landes that he holdes of the lordes of this Mannor but what the said landes are or howe he derives his title therevnto they doe not knowe, It is therefore desired that it be given to the Bailiffe in charge to somon the said Thomas Allen to appeare at next Courte to give informaion at the Courte & wee doe amerce him in v s. because he did not attende the homage to inform them more fully.

body.head: p 86 (3 October) ( Manor court, freeholders' inquest: defaulters)

div.ab:
Edwardus Allen Armiger ad
nichill./

head.title: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Dudley Carleton

div.ab: on sonday night here was a great fire at the Fortune in Golding-lane the fairest play-house in this towne, yt was quite burnt downe in two howres and all their apparell and play-bookes lost, wherby those poore companions are quite vndon: there were two other houses on fire but with great labour and daunger were saued.
Edward Alleyn, the owner of the Fortune, briefly notes the burning of his playhouse in a diary entry for 9 December 1621 (DCA: MS IX).

head.title: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Dudley Carleton

div.ab:
all the Lordes and great men about this towne go to visit and congratulate with the earle of Northumberland, the earle of Arundell supt with him the first night, and dined there the next day, whether came likewise vnbidden the Spanish ambassador, who is growne so affable and familiar, that on monday with his whole traine he went to
a common Play at the Fortune in Golding lane, and the players (not to be ouercome with curtesie) made him a banket when the play was don in the garden adioyning.

The earl of Northumberland had just been freed by James I after fifteen years' imprisonment, and the Spanish ambassador was Count Sarmiento de Acuña Gondomar. Three years later the King's Men, then playing at the Globe, would be in trouble for producing Thomas Middleton's allegorical play A Game at Chesse, dealing with the widely disliked, proposed Spanish marriage of Prince Charles, and attacking Gondomar. This was the subject of a protest to King James by the then Spanish Ambassador, Don Carlos Coloma, who had replaced Gondomar in 1622.

ab.hi: 8vo ffebruarij predicto coram Domino Iohanne Lambe milite &c.

row.cell: Contra Iohannem Shaunks vnum histrionum de le ffortune Playhouse/
Contra Iohannem Shaunks vnum histrionum de le ffortune playhouse/
he is examined & a moccion by dicto: H Clerke refered to sir Nathaniel Brent dicto:

div.ab: This day vppon moccion of the Counsell for ye office wife of the said Iohn Shankes it alledging that the said Shankes had income, or weekly allowance of out of the ffortune Play house where he was an actor/ & out they desired a competence rate for alimony to be allotted to the sayd wife it was now by the Cort referred to sir Nathanaell Brent to call before him the Steward or Receauer of the said Playhouse to b present his booke of shares out that it may appeare what the said said: d written over another letter Shankes his weekly paie comes to & out of that, and such other sourances of lyvelyhood as its the said Shankes hath to allott such com proporcionable mainteynance to his wife (wherein the said Shankes is now condemned)/ as he shall think fitt from Intimacion &c.

This case, brought before the court for ecclesiastical causes (also known as the High Commission) is evidence for the continuance of the Fortune playhouse into 1639. The attachment of John Shanks' earnings as a player and sharer at the Fortune playhouse in order to pay alimony to his wife gives a glimpse into the company's financial administration. His nuncupative will, which does not mention a wife or children, was proved in the prerogative court of Canterbury by Henry Hasard in 1656 (TNA: PRO PROB 10/837). John was probably the son of an earlier John Shanks of St Giles without Cripplegate, who died in 1636.

head.title: Letter of Edmund Rossingham to Edward, 2nd Viscount Conway

body.head: f 267* (8 May) ( Players at the Fortune fined)

div.ab: Thursdaie last, the Players of the Fortune were fined a 1000 li. for settinge vpp an Altar, a bason, and twoe Candlestickes, and boweing downe before it vpon the stage; And although they allegde it was an old playe revived, and an Altar to the heathen Godes, yet is was apparent, that this playe was revivd of purpose in contempt of the ceremonies of the Church, if my paper were not at an end, I would in large myselfe vpon this subject, to shewe what was said of Altars. the ceremonies… Altars: written vertically in the left margin

This extract forms part of a longer letter, covering ff 266–7v. For the pamphlet on the same episode,
Vox Borealis, probably by Richard Overton, printed in 1640—1641 (and also Northern Scout, published 1639), see under the same.

A Lettre to Sir Drew Drewry
Drew Drewry: in italic script knight, William Waud Esquire Clerke of the Councell, Thomas Fowler, Edward Vaughan, and Nicholas Collyns esquires Iustices of ye peace in the Countie of Middlesex. Wee are given to vnderstand by our very good Lord the Lord Willoughby, and other gentlemen and Inhabitauntes in the parishe of St Giles without Creplegate that there is a purpose, and Intent in some persons to erect a TheatreTheatre: in italic script in white Crosstreete neere vnto the Barres in that parte that ys in the countie of Middlesex, wherof there are to manie allreadie not farr from that place, And as yow knowe not Long sithence, yow receaved speciall Direction to pluck Downe those, and to see them Defaced, Therefore yf this newe erection should be suffered, yt would not onlie be an offence, and scandall to Divers, but a thinge that would greatly Displease her Maiestie These are therefore to will and Require yow in any case to take order that no soche
Theatre Theatre: in italic script or plaie howse be built there, or other howse to serve for soch vse, bothe to avoide the many Inconveniences that therby are Lyklie to ensue, to all the Inhabitantes, and the offence yat would be to her Maiestie, havinge heretofore given sufficient notice vnto yow of the great myslyke her Highnes hath of those publick & vayne buildinge for soche occacions yat breede Increase of Base, and Lewde people, and Divers other disorders. Therefore wee Requir yow not to faile forthwith to take order that the foresaid intended Buildinge maie be staied, and yf any be begon, to see the same quite Defaced. So &c./

Order of the Lordes for the restrainte of the imoderate vse and Companye
of Playhowses and Players.

ab.note:
Memorandum, that the alteracion and interlying of this order was by reason that the said order after the same was entred in the Booke came againe in question and Debate, and the said interlyninge & amendementes were sett Downe according to the laste Determinacion of their lordshipes.
Thomas Smith\

div.ab: Whereas diuers Complaintes haue bin heretofore made vnto the Lordes & others of her Maiestes priuye Counsell, of the manyfolde abuses and disorders that haue growen and do contynue by occasion of many houses, erected and employed in and about the Cittie ʌof London for Common stage playes And now verie latelie by reason of some Complainte exhibited by sondry persons againste the buyldinge of the like house in or near ʌ Golding Lane Longlane, by one Edward Allen a Servant of the right honorable the Lord Admyrall the matter aswell in generaltie touchinge all the saide houses for stage playes and the vse of playinge as in particular concerninge the saide house now in hand to be buylte in or neare ʌ \Golding longl Lane, hath bin broughte into question and consultacion ammonge theire Lordships. fforasmuch as it is manifestly knowen and graunted that the multitude of the saide houses, and the mysgouerment of them hath bin and is dayly occasion, of the ydle ryoutous, and dissolute living of great Nombers of people, that leavinge all such honest and painefull course of life as they should followe, doe meete and assemble there, and of many particular abuses and disorders that doe therevpon ensue; And yet Neuertheles it is considered that the vse and exercise of suche playes (not beinge euill in yt self) may with a good order and moderacion be suffered in a well gouerned state; and that her Maiestie beinge pleased at some tymes to take delight and recreation in the sight and hearinge of them, some order is fitt to be taken for the allowance and maynetenaunce of such persons as are thought meetest in that kinde to yealde her Maiestie recreation and delighte, and consequently of the houses that must serue for publike playinge to keepe them in exercise; To the ende therefore that both the greatest abuses of the playes and playinge houses may be redressed, and yet the aforesaide vse and moderation of them retained. The Lords and the reste of her Maiestes privie Counsell, with one and full consent haue ordered in manner and forme as followeth.

ffirste, that there shalbe aboute the Cittie two houses and no more, allowed to serue for the vse of the Common stage playes; of the which houses one shalbe in Surrey, Surrey: in italic script in that place which is Commonly called the Banckeside or thereaboutes and theother in
Middlesex Middlesex: in italic script. And forasmuch as their Lordships haue bin enformed by Edmund Tylney
Edmund Tylney : in italic script esquire her Maiestes Servante and Master of the Revelles that the house nowe in hand to be builte by the saide Edward Allen is not intended to encrease the Nomber of the play houses but to be insteede of an other (namely the
Curtayne Curtayne: in italic script) which is ether to be ruyned and plucked downe or to be put to some other good vse as also that the scytuation thereof is meete and convenient for that purpose, it is like wise ordered that the saide house of Allen shalbe allowed to be one of the two houses, and namely for the house to be allowed in
Middlesex Middlesex: in italic script ɬfor the Company of players belonging to the Lord Admyrall so as the house called the
Curtaine Curtaine: in italic script be (as it ʌis hath bin pretended) either ruynated or applyed to some other good vse And for the other house allowed to be in
Surrey Surrey: in italic script side whereas ɬtheir lordships are pleased to permitt : 155mm of cancelled text illegible to the Company of players that shall play there to make their owne Choice which they will haue [of diuers houses that are there choosing one of them and no more

ɬAnd ye said company of plaiers beinge the Servantes of the lord Chamberlain that are to play there haue made choise of the house called the Globe, it is ordered that the said house and none other shalbe there allowed.And especially it is forbidden that any stage playes shalbe played (as some tymes they haue bin) in any Common Inne for publique assembly in or neare about the Cittie./

Secondly, forasmuch as these stage plaies, by the multitude of houses and company of players haue bin to frequent not servinge for recreation but invitinge and callinge the people dayly from their trade and worke to misspend their tyme
it is likewise ordered that the two seuerall Companies of players assigned vnto the two houses allowed may play each of them in their seuerall houses twice a weeke and no oftener, and especially that they shall refrayne to play on the Sabbath Sabbath: in italic script day vpon paine of imprysonment and further penaltie: and that they shall forbeare altogether in the tyme of Lent and likewise at such tyme & tymes as any extraordinary sicknes or infection of disease shall appeare to be in or about the Cittie./

Thirdly because the orders wilbe of little force and effecte vnlesse they be duely put in execution, by those vnto whome it appertayneth to see them executed; It is ordered that seuerall Copies of these orders shalbe sent to the Lord Maiour of London; and to the Iustices of the peace of the Counties of Middlesex and Surrey. and that Lettres shalbe written vnto them from their Lordships, straightly charginge them to see to the execucion of the same, aswell by Comyttinge to prison any Owners of play houses and players as shall disobey and resist these orders , as by any other good and Lawfull meanes that in their discretion they shall finde expedient, and to certifie their Lordships from tyme to tyme, as they shall see cause of their proceedinges herein.

This letter, with minor differences, is also to be found in Remembrancia (LMA: COL/RMD/PA/01/002, no. 188). The warrant from Charles Howard, earl of Nottingham, for the building of the Fortune, dated 12 January 1559/1600, indicates that it is playhouse in Bankside that Alleyn's new ' house' is intended to replace, not the Curtain (DCA: MS I, Article 27).

ab.note: Prince's Players Warrant to exercise their art & faculties &c.

div.ab:
A licence for the Princes players to exercise the art and facultie of playing tragedies Comedies histories pastoralles &c as well within their howse called the
Fortune Fortune: in italic script in the Countie of Middlesex as elswhere in convenient places within this Realme of England for the recreacion of his Maiestes subiectes during his highness pleasure.

row.cell: A Commission graunted vnto Thomas Downton William Bird Edward Iuby Samuell Rowle Charles Massey, Humfrey Ieffes ffranck Grace William Cartwright, Edward Colbrand William Parr, William Stratford. Richard Gunell ʌ Iohn Shanck and Richard Price, servantes to his Maiestes sonne in Lawe the Electour Palatine, and the rest of their Associates to vse and exercise the art and facultie of playing Comedies Histories Enterludes Morralls Pastoralls Stageplayes , and such other like ʌas well within their now vsuall howse called the ffortune within the Counties of Middlesex, as also within any other Convenient places within the libertie or freedome of any Citie or Towne wheresouer within ʌd Realm his Maiestes Realmes & Dominions during his highness pleasure. procured by Sir Thomas Lake.
